The adaptation scenario shows that 2012 analogs are approximately 11 times (SSP1-2.6) or 16 times (SSP5-8.5) more likely to occur in the no adaptation scenario than in the adaptation scenario. Reporting the lower factor.
The average magnitude of the analogs is 15% higher in the no adaptation scenario than in the adaptation for SSP5-8.5.
The average magnitude of the analogs is 4% higher in the no adaptation scenario than in the adaptation for SSP1-2.6.
2012 analogs are 16 times more likely to occur in the no adaptation scenario than in the adaptation scenario for the SSP5-8.5.
2012 analogs are 11 times more likely to occur in the no adaptation scenario than in the adaptation scenario for the SSP1-2.6.

The risk of 2012 analogs is roughly 11 and 16 times less frequent and on average 4% and 15% less intense for SSP1-2.6 when removing the trends in mean climate and considering only changes in climate variability, representing potential impacts if adaptation does not keep pace with climate change.
